moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nc3: Pillsbury intends to drive his KBP forward, so he doesn't yet move his KN.
moves.2... Nc6: The amateur responds with symmetry, unsure of how to handle Pillsbury's unusual opening.
moves.3. f4: In effect, a delayed King's Gambit.
moves.3... d6: Declining the gambit, a move that even by a grandmaster leads to equality at best. The proper way to refute the King's Gambit is to accept the Pawn and return it later for a positional advantage.
moves.4. Nf3: Now that his KBP is advanced, Pillsbury can develop this Knight.
moves.4... a6: A wasted move. The pin was no real threat.
moves.5... Bg4: Apparently the amateur is unaware of the Legal pitfall.
moves.6. fxe5: The junction point. The correct reply is 6... PxP!
moves.6... Nxe5: This move loses the game, either quickly or slowly.
moves.7. Nxe5: Black can lose slowly by conceding a piece: 7... PxN 8 QxB, and White has a long but easy win with his material advantage.
moves.7... Bxd1: Black chooses to die quickly. Mate in 2 follows.
moves.9. Nd5#: A classic trap, well executed by Pillsbury.
